headline.main: Macedonia to Ask NATO Force to Stay

lead_paragraph: Macedonia's prime minister said today that NATO troops would be asked to extend their stay into 2002 to help cement an accord with ethnic Albanian rebels. His statement was the first definite word from Macedonia's government that it would accept NATO's advice to extend for three months, beginning Jan. 1, the mandate of 1,000 troops to guard civilian monitors and defuse tensions between security forces and the former rebels.
abstract: Prime Min Ljubco Georgievski, after meeting with Pres Boris Trajkovski, says NATO troops should stay in Macedonia into 2002 to help cement accord with ethnic Albanian rebels; state National Security Council reportedly backs call (M)
